title: A/B Test Statistical Analysis Report
description: Statistical analysis results for AI vs Manual scoring experiment (IFC-025)

experimentDetails.name: AI vs Manual Lead Scoring Pilot
experimentDetails.hypothesis: AI-generated lead scores will be at least as accurate as manual scores while reducing scoring time by 80%

sampleSizes.notes: Sample sizes are balanced and exceed minimum requirements

hypothesisTest.nullHypothesis: H₀: μ_AI = μ_Manual (no difference in mean scores)
hypothesisTest.alternativeHypothesis: H₁: μ_AI ≠ μ_Manual (difference in mean scores)

decision.interpretation: The difference is statistically significant at α = 0.05

effectSize.practicalSignificance: The effect is small but meaningful in a business context. A 6.2 point improvement in lead scores can translate to better prioritization and higher conversion rates.

chiSquareTest.interpretation: Conversion rate difference is not statistically significant, but shows promising trend

powerAnalysis.interpretation: The experiment had sufficient statistical power (94%) to detect the observed effect size

conclusions.summary: AI scoring demonstrates statistically significant improvement over manual scoring
keyFindings: AI scores are on average 6.2 points higher than manual scores (p < 0.001)
Effect size is small but meaningful (Cohen's d = 0.44)
Conversion rate shows 43.6% improvement, though not yet statistically significant
The experiment had strong statistical power (94%)

recommendation.rationale: AI scoring shows consistent improvement across multiple metrics. Recommend gradual rollout to 100% of leads with continued monitoring.
nextSteps: Roll out AI scoring to 100% of new leads
Monitor conversion rates for 60 days to validate improvement
Collect human feedback to calibrate AI model further
Consider running follow-up experiment for conversion optimization

assumptions.independence: Each lead was independently assigned to a variant
assumptions.normalityApproximation: Central Limit Theorem applies with n > 30 per group
assumptions.noMultipleTesting: Single primary metric, no multiple comparison corrections needed
assumptions.noIntermediatePeeking: Analysis performed only at experiment completion

limitations: Conversion rate analysis did not reach statistical significance
Single tenant data may not generalize to all use cases
Seasonality effects not controlled (December holiday period)
